bestBHT.bht: The jailer, aware of the consequences of escaped prisoners, was about to take his own life upon finding the prison doors open, as suicide was common in desperate situations. However, the earthquake that shook the prison woke him up and saved him from self-destruction. This earthquake not only displayed God's power, but it also served as a wakeup call for the jailer, ultimately leading to the salvation of Paul and Silas.

Henry Alford: The law was, that if a prisoner escaped, the keeper was liable to the intended punishment of the fugitive.
Philippi is famous in the annals of suicide.
Mr. Howson notices, by the examples of Cassius, Brutus, Titinius, and many of the proscribed, after the battle...
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: drew . . . his sword, and would have killed himself, c.—knowing
that his life was forfeited in that case ( :- and compare Acts 27:42).
Albert Barnes: It should be added that it was common and approved among the Greeks and Romans for a man to commit suicide when he was encompassed with dangers from which he could not escape.
The custom was thus sanctioned by the authority and example of the great; and we are not to wonder that the jailor, in a moment of alarm, should also attempt to destroy his own life.
It is not one of the least benefits of Christianity that it has proclaimed the evil of self-murder, and has done so much to drive it from the world.
Marvin Vincent: Would have killed [εμελλεν αναιρειν] . Rev., more correctly, was about to kill. Knowing that he must suffer death for the escape of his prisoners.
John Calvin: He doth so yield to the petitions of Paul and Silas, that he showeth that he is able enough to deliver them so often as he shall think it good; and that nothing can hinder him, but that he is able to enter not only into prisons, but also into graves, that he may deliver those that be his.
Now, forasmuch as he had another way in readiness to deliver Paul and Silas, he meant not so much to deliver them for the present time by miracle, as to confirm them against the time to come.

Whence we gather that he was holden by God, as the Lord useth to direct the minds of those which be his in doubtful matters, that they may follow sometimes ignorantly, sometimes wittingly, that which is expedient to be done, and not pass their bounds.
Philip Schaff: The jailor or governor of the prison seeing the doors open, naturally concluded that his prisoners... had fled...
Howson remarks that Philippi is famous in the annals of suicide... Self-murder among the Romans in the first and second centuries of the Christian era was fearfully common.

It was, in fact, the common resort in trouble and in extreme danger, and was not unknown even in cases where satiety in all life’s pleasures had induced the not uncommon feeling of utter weariness of living.
Archibald T. Robertson: An earthquake like that would wake up any one.
He was on the point of committing suicide as Brutus had done near here.
Probably the prisoners were so panic stricken by the earthquake that they did not rally to the possibility of escape before the jailor awoke.
John Gill: Not so much by the loud voices of Paul and Silas, as by the uncommon motion of the earth, which so shook him, as thoroughly to awake him.
He drew out his sword... and would have killed himself, supposing that the prisoners had been fled.
In fear of the magistrates, and what they would inflict upon him, he was just going to destroy himself.

bhtAttempts.bht: The jailer, knowing that if prisoners escaped he would face severe punishment, was on the verge of taking his own life when he saw the prison doors opened. This act of desperation was not uncommon in that time and place, as suicide was often seen as an acceptable response to great danger. However, the earthquake that had shaken the prison awakened him and prevented him from carrying out his plan. The earthquake showed God's power and ultimately saved Paul and Silas, but it also served as a wake-up call to the jailer. This event not only led to the jailer's physical salvation, but also planted seeds for his spiritual salvation in the future.
